review.title: Abstract Argumentation / Persuasion / Dynamics
review.abstract: The act of persuasion, a key component in rhetoric argumentation, may be viewed as a dynamics modifier. Such modifiers are well-known in other research fields: recall dynamic epistemic logic where operators modify possible world accessibilities, or recall side effects and concurrency in programming languages. We consider persuasion in abstract argumentation as undertaking a similar role. We extend Dung's frameworks with acts of persuasion among agents into Abstract Persuasion Argumentation (APA), and set forth properties related to arguments' admissibilities. We show a way of enriching our basic notion of admissibility through CTL (computation tree logic) encoding, which also permits importation of the theoretical results known to the logic into our argumentation frameworks.

sections.text: Abstract Argumentation / Persuasion / Dynamics Ryuta ArisakaNational Institute of Informatics ryutaarisaka @ gmail.com Ken Satoh National Institute of Informaticsksatoh @ nii.ac.jpABSTRACT The act of persuasion, a key component in rhetorical reasoning, can be considered a dynamics modifier. Such modifiers are also known in other fields of research: remember dynamic epistemic logic, in which operators modify possible accessibility of the world, or remember side effects and parallels in programming languages. We consider conviction in abstract reasoning to have a similar role. We expand Dung's frameworks to include persuasion work among actors in Abstract Persuasion Argumentation (APA) and outline characteristics related to the admissibility of arguments. We show a way to enrich our fundamental notion of admissibility through CTL (computation tree logic) encoding, the theoretical results of which are also allowed to import the theoretical results of our arguments.

sections.text: An interesting component of rhetoric reasoning is persuasion work. There may be various reasons for the persuasive action. It may be that A is a great teacher who wants to correct some unrecommended norms of B, or perhaps A is a manipulator who benefits when a2 is absent. Convinction work is commonly observed in social forums such as YouTube and Twitter, and methods of representing it will help to understand users "views on topics precisely. Another less pervasive form of persuasion work is possible: a1 © (a1 B: a3 ©, in which A convinces B with a3 in the utterance of a3, but without conversion.) Convinction work acts as a motivator in the argumentation.

sections.heading: 1.1 Example situations
sections.text: It is necessary to keep pigs in good health. All animals are equal. It is for a power to control social norms. Although it was written for the general public, it has many critical components of rhetoric reasoning, such as the use of pseudo-logic, scapegoat and half-truths by Chris Bob Jones to convince other agents. In the story, farm animals chase their farm owner Jones in order to govern the farm itself, but ultimately they correct the above standards in all animals are equal to be persecuted by all animals. Pigs take a leading role of indoctrinating other animals and running the farm, which have gradually gained a dominant influence on other animals. Last they the above animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others, which is the restoration of tyranny against farm animals once united. We extract some arguments from the novella.

sections.heading: 3.2 Conclusion with related work
sections.text: We have identified a new research direction for abstract reasoning with dynamic operators of persuasive actions on dung's framework (26). We have outlined important characteristics and terms and demonstrated that embedding the "current admissibility" in CTL for various admissibilities is likely to follow. Our contribution is promising for bringing together knowledge of abstract reasoning in AI and techniques and issues of consistency in program analysis in the very near future. Cross-studies in the two areas are highly anticipated. Indeed, the study of concurrent aspects of reasoning are important for assessing shifts of opinion that affect the development of more effective sales approaches and better marketing in the economy, and consensus control tactics in politics. Exploiting our study with probabilistic methods is likely to be exciting research. Our current plan is to take into account nuances of persuasive actions such as pseudo-logic, threats and half-truths in addition.
